messages: 70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:19): Well, guess what, guys.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:20): The website works so well in HTML5 that we're going to move the entire product to HTML5.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:20): Hah, awesome!
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:20): Yea ... kinda nervous about that one, though I pushed this.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:25): What HTML5 features did you use here?
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:27): On our website?
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:28): Mostly structural to build the website as an outline, but we're also using <video> with a graceful flash fallback.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:30): And this really gives you serious concrete benefits?  I'm a big fan of HTML5, but it's only marginally useful so far as far as I can tell.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:31): Well, it's the way the web is going, and nobody else is seriously going for it, so we figure it worked so well for the website

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:31): Like, I wouldn't use <video> with Flash fallback except as opt-in, since it doesn't support things like fullscreen (except in FF3.6) . . . I'd make it opt-in and/or use Flash with <video> fallback.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:31): bam, let's do it.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:31): I've been trying to get Wikipedia to switch, but it's backlogged way too much on code review, so it hasn't deployed my new less-broken HTML5-enabling code yet.  :(
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:31): Well, marginally is the name of the game
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:31): HTML5 elements in use in the core product would be, hgroup, nav, section, article
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:32): You don't have an atomic HTML5 vs not
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:32): probably header and footer as well, though I'm still not sure how the W3C or WHATWG wants us to use them.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:32): Just a large set of tiny changes that mesh together
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:32): 70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132, so you have the JS hack for IE?
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:32): Yes.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:32): And we haven't received a single complaint about it.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:33): And traffic is very high on our site from the enterprise end, who would be the ones on the lowest end machines.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:33): No complaints about not being able to see the videos either, in fact, only a few compliments from developers who noticed the <video> implementation.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:33): For those who don't know what we did, they didn't even notice.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:35): Oi, just feel like I'm playing with the fetus of fire.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:36): This reminds me, I have to re-add IE5.0 and 5.5 CSS support to MediaWiki.  Someone gratuitously removed it.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:37): Do you really have to?
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:37): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762, what were the benefits of adding it back in?
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:37): And what were the benefits of taking it out?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:37): The only benefit of taking it out is two lines saved in the <head>.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:38): The benefit of adding it back in is tens of thousands of IE5 users will still be able to read Wikipedia.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:38): Probably hundreds of thousands.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:38): Hmm, well, at least if you assume they view at about the same rate as other users.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:39): I'm guessing you don't pay heed to the moral argument of not aiding and abetting entrenchment of outdated browsers :)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:40): No, Wikimedia's goal is to make knowledge freely available to everyone.  Not only to people who use up-to-date browsers.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:40): *Personally*, well, you can look at the source code of http://aryeh.name/ to see my attitude there.  :P
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:40): Tens of thousands of IE5 users?
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:40): Are you sure you're not talking about IE6?
b72896c7178566c0f4f70bdf50401389 (18:41): IE6 still has many millions of users.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:42): I'm talking about IE5, on Wikipedia.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:42): Wikipedia has hundreds of millions of users.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:42): IE5 is not down to 0.01% market share yet.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:42): Sure, and I honestly didn't know tens of thousands of them (I understand it's a small percentage) were still using IE5.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:42): You think IE5 is all the way down to 0.01%?
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:43): I thought it wasn't even listed anymore.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:43): The statistic that was given as justification for the removal was 0.3%, which would be hundreds of thousands of users.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:44): Yea, I can understand that.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:44): You are correct, not that you needed me to say that.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:44): http://stats.wikimedia.org/wikimedia/squids/SquidReportClients.htm
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:45): Actually, you were closer to correct.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:45): Still thousands of hits, but possibly only hundreds of users.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:46): Oh, wait, that's times a thousand.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:46): So about 5,000,000 hits from IE5.5.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:46): Did the removal of the two lines kill IE5.5 though?
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:46): I thought IE5.5 was its own beast.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:47): One line was for IE5, one was for IE5.5.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:47): I wonder how many of those are bots pretending to be ie
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:47): If you could cross-reference requests to pages with requests to style sheets...
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (18:47): http://lists.xml.org/archives/xml-dev/201002/msg00064.html
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:48): a couple of years ago I was looking at my logs and concluded most ie5 requests weren't from browsers
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:48): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9, that's an idea, we could look at the stats for how often those particular stylesheets were requested.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:48): Bots wouldn't request stylesheets either.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:48): GranParadiso was the FF 3.0 alpha, wasn't it?
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (18:49): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: it's not done every month?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:49): 1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167, I dunno, I don't see newer data.

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:50): 1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167: Is that list open to post to?  I can provide reasoning for why, frex, data urls were rejected as a solution.

a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:52): Namaroka is supposed to be 3.6

70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:04): I noticed that the WHATWG example for HTML5 shows <nav><h2>Navigation</h2> ... </nav> without an <h1>
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:04): Why is that?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:05): The absolute values of the numbers are meaningless
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:05): (Only relative values matter)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:06): So I guess the example is attempting to demonstrate that it's valid to do that
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:06): Also, using lower numbers sometimes can be helpful for no-CSS display in legacy browsers.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:06): So <h1> or <h2> would have been fine, it's completely arbitrary unless relative to another <h*>
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:08): I've read somewhere that <hgroup> is a specialised form of <header>, but that would not appear true.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:08): <hgroup> is for grouping headers and subheaders
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:08): So they aren't interpreted as separate headings
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:08): Nah, it's just a way to group multiple <hn> into a single heading, so it won't mess up the outline.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:09): Right, that's what I thought.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:09): That's how we're using them.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:18): Okay guys, let me share my "strategy" for HTML5 in our product.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:18): I can pastie it, actually.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:19): http://pastie.org/833062
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:21): Why bother with <html>, <head>, <body>?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:21): They're implicit.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:22): You don't need the /> in the meta, <meta charset="UTF-8"> will work fine.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:22): Also, why <header id="header">?  What's the id needed for?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:22): Likewise <nav id="navigation">, etc.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:22): Part of the point of those elements is so you don't need those id's.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:23): You also have some div wrappers of unclear purpose -- do you need those for styling?
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:23): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762, yes the div wrappers are there for style guys to muck around with the content.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:24): the IDs are important because they target a particular singular instance versus a generic element which can exist elsewhere in the site.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:25): Calling them something like id="main-header" might help disambiguate them, and stop people asking why that header is header and other headers aren't header
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:25): Or you could put a class or id on the body element and use that.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:25): So you'd only need one class instead of lots of id's.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:26): Or, better yet, just stick with no id's or classes at all until you actually need them.  That's what I've done so far for my personal site, although admittedly it only has a few pages.

70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:26): Well, I don't see how that would be easier 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762, I'd still end up having .someBodyClassName > div > header or something to specifically target those elements, that's what IDs and classnames are for.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:26): I've used "body > header" to target my top-level stuff.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:26): That's what selectors are for.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:27): Especially if you don't need IE support, then you barely need classes/ids at all.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:27): We'll need IE support.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:27): Also, it's easier for a web designer to target an ID than moving through selectors.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:27): Well, IE6 is the problem there.  Doesen't support child selectors.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:28): So an #id helps there.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:28): Yeah.  Sigh.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:28): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762, not to mention that it's easier to develop on.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:29): id is implicit that it is unique to the page, the only instance, therefore #header and #footer mean "The ONE header" and "The ONE footer"
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:49): Okay updated @ http://pastie.org/833113
